Iran must stop conducting and backing terrorism before we ever take the step of removing the terrorism sanctions that have been successfully implemented since 2018.
 
https://www.state.gov/reports/country-reports-on-terrorism-2019/iran/

We should never remove terrorism sanctions so long as Iran is conducting or backing terrorist attacks on us or our allies. Look no further than the attack this month that targeted Americans in Iraq. Does anyone think there was no Iranian involvement?  
 
https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/global-opinions/biden-cant-negotiate-with-iran-as-its-proxies-attack-us-troops/2021/02/18/096b1580-7228-11eb-85fa-e0ccb3660358_story.html
If the Biden team gives a new wave of financial relief, expect Iran to double down on terrorism.

We saw this approach fail before. Starting in 2015, Iran spent the deal‚Äôs massive financial windfall on military & terrorism. The result was a regional disaster until US, Israel & other allies pushed back. 

https://www.reuters.com/article/us-iran-military-plan/iran-to-expand-military-spending-develop-missiles-idUSKBN14T15L
Our hard-won terrorism sanctions aim directly at these threats.

And what about Israel and our other allies in Iran‚Äôs neighborhood? For them, the nuclear issue is not the only existential threat from Iran. They face grave and growing threats every day from Iranian missiles, cyberattacks, terrorists & militant proxies. 

https://www.reuters.com/article/iran-nuclear-israel-int/iran-vows-decisive-response-to-any-israeli-move-against-it-idUSKBN29A2D6

Many in Europe are begging the U.S. to re-engage with Iran, because European businesses are desperate to do business with Iran but they need our sanctions lifted. We should stand w/allies who stand with us, but America‚Äôs policy shouldn't be #EuropeFirst.
 
https://www.reuters.com/article/iran-germany-sanctions-banks-exclusive/european-allies-pushed-back-when-trump-sanctioned-irans-banks-idUSKBN28B59T

The Biden-Euro statement suggests Iran‚Äôs missiles, terrorism, hostage-taking & human rights abuses are problems to address after nuclear issue. But if we lift our powerful sanctions to revive a flawed agreement, we then forfeit the leverage necessary to deal with other threats.

The signal from Team Biden is yes. We know Iran was told ‚Äúwait ‚Äòem out til we get back.‚Äô  (#LoganAct?). @POTUS Biden: Don‚Äôt give away our leverage for a headline . . . 
 
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-iran-pompeo/pompeo-slams-kerry-for-inappropriate-meetings-with-iran-officials-idUSKCN1LU2NY

This is important: Iran‚Äôs central bank & state oil and tanker companies are now penalized not just by nuclear sanctions, but also by terrorism sanctions. So will the Biden team lift both nuclear & terrorism sanctions here just to bribe Iran into complying with flawed deal?

Yesterday‚Äôs U.S.-E3 statement on the Iran nuclear deal raises big questions. Let‚Äôs take a closer look. The Biden Team pledges that if Iran takes some modest steps to re-enter the deal, we‚Äôll lift vast & powerful sanctions that took years to impose. https://www.state.gov/joint-statement-by-the-secretary-of-state-of-the-united-states-of-america-and-the-foreign-ministers-of-france-germany-the-united-kingdom/

Childcare costs were skyrocketing long before the pandemic, but the mass exodus of women from the workforce‚Äîmany of whom are citing childcare responsibilities‚Äîhas made reducing the cost even more urgent. I spoke with @19thnews about what we can do ‚¨áÔ∏è

Casey is well respected among lawmakers and staffers alike, and is a wealth of knowledge on tax policy. As Staff Director for Ways and Means, Casey helps move critical tax legislation to law.

After completing both his B.A. and J.D. at Marquette University, Brandon Casey knew he wanted to head back to Capitol Hill to work in politics.

Brandon Casey has spent more than a decade successfully seeing his post-collegiate vision come to fruition.

Brandon Casey is a Chicago native. Raised on the South Side by a single parent, Casey defied odds to become one of the first members of his family to complete his undergraduate degree. While in college, Casey interned with the Congressional Black Caucus's own Rep. Bobby Rush.

#BrandonCasey is the first Black Chief of Staff for the House Committee on Ways and Means. Previously, Casey served as Legislative Director and Tax Counsel for Rep. Richard Neal, and served as Tax Counsel for former Rep. Allyson Schwartz. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EunHbz6WQAAMEPi.jpg

Today, I was proud to once again speak, this year virtually, with our local students to tell them my story, & urge them to listen to the voices & remember the struggles of those who were discriminated against. Out of this respect we all grow from our collective experiences.

#DayofRemembrance stands as a time to reflect on these injustices so that they never happen again and remind our younger generations of the work that remains to build a more inclusive, equitable future for us all.

Over the past few years, we have seen how volatile and racially charged policy can quickly become normalized. Divisive rhetoric can spiral into the recent violence against AAPI communities. That is why we look to the past for guidance.

79 years ago, Executive Order 9066 stripped over 120,000 Japanese Americans, including my parents, of their most basic civil rights ‚Äì using fear as an excuse for discrimination, racism and injustice.

Tenemos que evitar que esta administraci√≥n desperdicie la oportunidad de mantenerse en solidaridad con el derecho a ser libre de los cubanos. https://videos.americateve.com/m/j7W3yAMf/el-congresista-mario-daz-balart-enva-un-fuerte-mensaje-a-la-administracin-biden-sobre-las-relaciones-cuba-eeuu?list=3GKsigBs

This is particularly important given the recent rise in violent crime perpetrated against Asian Americans and Pacific Islanders. It is my hope that we take lessons from this terrible era to heart, and honor those who were devastated in the very country they called home.

Last Congress, I proudly joined my friend, Congresswoman @DorisMatsui, in the introduction of the Japanese American Confinement Education Act, which took crucial steps to educate younger generations about the horrors of Japanese internment.
Tragically, many of our young people no longer study this terrible moment in history, which puts our ability to learn lessons from this era at risk.

In 1988, I was proud to support the Civil Liberties Act, which took crucial steps to acknowledge our nation‚Äôs wrongdoing and to recommit ourselves to never letting racially-based incarceration happen again.

The forced internment of our fellow citizens through Executive Order 9066 is one of the darkest chapters in American history. The fact that it occurred during my lifetime highlights just how fresh a wound this is for Japanese Americans across our country.

On this annual #DayOfRemembrance, we reflect on President Franklin D. Roosevelt‚Äôs signing of Executive Order 9066, which forced 120,000 Japanese Americans into internment camps. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EunPj56XUAE_4Vq.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EunPkonXEAU_wjE.png http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EunPmC4XYAAf-yH.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EunPnkRXMAIIiqE.jpg

Violence against AAPI isn‚Äôt just an AAPI problem. But also anti-AAPI descrimination is not the only discrimination that AAPIs should care about. Hate/racism in all forms is despicable. I don‚Äôt claim to fully understand the deep racism others face but we lift each other up. 17/19

We need the development of thicker and more sustained grassroots engagement that so often feels lacking in AAPI political outreach. And we need to ensure that this effort has a wide coalition beyond just the AAPI community. 16/19

We need voices at all levels of gov speaking out. Need Governors to come up with their own state-level plans and to meaningfully reach out to AAPI communities in their states. We need a punchlist of what local municipalities and law enforcement need to take this seriously. 15/19

Congress should pass the NO HATE ACT to put more resources to tackling hate crimes in our nation (the House passed it in May 2020). We should hold hearings to shine light on this violence as well as other discriminatory concerns and give AAPI community a greater voice. 14/19

We need Biden team to prioritize re-establishing White House Initiative on AAPI to create a designated portal for sustained engagement and relationship building with AAPI communities around the country. 13/19

So what do we do? We need the Biden admin to designate a point person on hate crimes and to direct DoJ and FBI to allocate more resources including creation of single reporting channel to flag discriminatory actions, hate crimes training, and real AAPI community outreach. 12/19

PROVING WORTH: When I‚Äôm asked about why gov should engage with AAPI, I‚Äôm often hit with stats about fastest growing demographic and margin of victory in GA runoffs. All true. But we shouldn‚Äôt have to justify worth. We are worth protecting not just because of usefulness. 11/19

REMOVAL: What I experienced is but a mere speck compared to the scars of Japanese Americans rounded up in internment camps. Today is the Remembrance Day for that stain on our history. Our government did this. We must remember. 10/19 http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Eumo6MKXEAAsf6D.jpg

This letter was completely unprompted. I can tell you exactly how it feels to have your own government say ‚Äúwe don‚Äôt trust you,‚Äù even after I worked in warzones on behalf of our nation. It hurt, still does. 9/19

LOYALTY TEST: I worked for years as a diplomat at the State Dept. Top Secret clearance working on the wars in Iraq/Afghanistan. But State Dept one day sent me a letter saying I could not work on any issues related to Korea. I was confused because I never requested to do so. 8/19

OTHERIZATION: When I ran for Congress in 2018, a TV ad ended with the line ‚ÄúAndy Kim, he‚Äôs not one of us.‚Äù They tried to say I‚Äôm foreign, I‚Äôm not American no matter what, that I‚Äôm an ‚Äúother.‚Äù Sadly not the first time I experienced this type of attack questioning my loyalty. 7/19 http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Eumo5z6XUAA7sBg.jpg

COWARDICE: Attacking our elders is also the most cowardly way to show hate. Violence against frailty is despicable and demonstrates a particular insecurity. Sadly it also demonstrates an absence of decency that has been filled by anger.  6/19

CUT DEEP: Our elders are our roots. They are often the ones who had the infinite courage to journey to America and build a new life in pursuit of the American dream. Attacking them makes us feel like we are weeds being pulled up by our roots. This is no doubt intentional. 5/19

DISRESPECT: When I yelled at my grandma, I disrespected her. I disrespected my family‚Äôs history. I disrespect what others did to give me what I have. When people attack AAPIs, they disrespect our shared history and our place. 4/19

Yes, some is covid-related discrimination inflamed by the former president, but that is not the whole story though it is what the media often latches onto. The history of anti-AAPI sentiment is long but often unseen or forgotten, representing several principles of hate. 3/19

A 91 year old Asian American man assaulted. Hit so hard his frail body goes completely airborne. Another in his 80s killed by a stranger. Another slashed by a knife across his face. They could be my grandparents, your parents or grandparents. 2/19 http://pbs.twimg.com/media/Eumo5T5WgAM7VL-.jpg

I have only one memory of my grandma and it isn‚Äôt a good one. She visited America when I was a child. Instead of embracing her I yelled at her to go home. I‚Äôve regretted that my whole life.
